DOC.HEAD: Cuban Seeks U.N. Meeting on Panama
DOC.TEXT: Cuba on Tuesday requested an urgent meeting of the U.N. Security Council to condemn Washington for ordering troops to circle the Cuban Embassy in Panama during the hunt for Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. No meeting was scheduled during informal council consultations Tuesday night, but the question could be considered again. Cuban Ambassador Oscar Oramas Oliva made the request in his second letter in two days to Security Council President Enrique Penalosa of Colombia. He said that people in the Cuban ambassador's residence in Panama City and in the embassy were virtual prisoners. At least 25 children and 30 women were being prevented from leaving, he said, calling the U.S. action a violation of international law and infringement upon the rights of diplomatic personnel. U.S. troops surrounded the Nicaraguan and Cuban embassies in Panama City on Thursday after rumors surfaced that Noriega may be hiding in one of the missions. Noriega turned himself in Sunday to the Vatican mission in Panama City. Last week, the council met at the request of Nicaragua, which sought to condemn the U.S. invasion of Panama. But the United States, Britain and France on Saturday vetoed a resolution that would have deplored the U.S. military action and demanded immediate withdrawal of U.S. forces.
